thermal.thermal_stability: thermally stable at 300K after Li adsorption
thermally stable at 300K after Na adsorption

characterization_evidence: X-ray diffraction (compared to Hotje et al.19)

site_distribution.site_specificity: both interstitial and substitutional can co-exist

characterization_evidence: X-ray diffraction (compared to Hotje et al.19)

synthesis_conditions.additional_parameters: 1M LiPF6 in EC/DMC (1:1 vol%), C/35 cycling rate, voltage range 3.000-0.001 V vs Li/Li+

site_distribution.site_specificity: Staging observed, forming various LixC6 phases

structural_changes.phase_transition: Formation of different LixC6 phases (stage IL, IV, III, IIL, II, I)

distribution_characteristics.uniformity: Initially slight gradient from separator side, later relatively homogeneous for LiC6, delayed lithiation/delithiation in central region

characterization_evidence: Neutron imaging: Li distribution and SEI formation
Neutron diffraction: LixC6 phase identification and quantification

synthesis_conditions.additional_parameters: Two-zone furnace with temperature gradient; Chlorine gas as transport agent

characterization_evidence: Magnetic susceptibility: change in magnetic behavior

synthesis_conditions.additional_parameters: rf power 100W, frequency 50kHz, gas flow rate 15 sccm

site_distribution.site_specificity: MoO3 rich disordered domains formation, replacing S atoms and causing lattice distortion.

electronic.other_electronic: on-current decreased by >4 orders of magnitude, resistance increased by >4 orders of magnitude.

characterization_evidence: Raman spectroscopy: decrease in MoS2 peak intensity, appearance of MoO3 peaks
XPS: Mo 3d peak for Mo+6 state confirms MoO3
Electrical measurements (ID-VG, ID-VDS): mobility and on-current decrease, resistance increases exponentially with plasma time

synthesis_conditions.additional_parameters: Electrolyte: LiTFSI/PEO, Magnetic field: 0.5 T, Sweep rate: ~1 mV/s

structural_changes.defect_formation: Voids (~1 nm) and cracks in MoS2

optical.photoluminescence: Quenched after full intercalation; Trion (A-) peak appears before quenching

characterization_evidence: In situ magnetoresistance and Hall measurements

synthesis_conditions.additional_parameters: Electrolyte: LiTFSI/PEO, Magnetic field: 0.5T, Sweep rate: ~1 mV/s

characterization_evidence: In situ magnetoresistance and Hall measurements

synthesis_conditions.additional_parameters: Electrolyte: LiTFSI/PEO, Magnetic field: 0.5T, Sweep rate: ~1 mV/s

site_distribution.site_specificity: Primarily at the MoS2/graphene interface, less at MoS2/MoS2 or MoS2/hBN

carrier_concentration.change_factor: Similar to structure II, despite more MoS2

characterization_evidence: In situ magnetoresistance and Hall measurements

synthesis_conditions.substrate_pretreatment: repeated cycles of sputtering (Ar+ ions at an energy of 1 keV), followed by two-step annealing at 1173 K under O2 atmosphere (3×10-8 mbar) and at 1233 K subsequently

site_distribution.site_specificity: geometrically low regions of the moiré superlattice, forms small aggregates

electronic.other_electronic: Dirac point remains largely unchanged (~24 ± 5 mV above Fermi level)

characterization_evidence: XPS: B 1s peak confirms B presence, C 1s shows C-B bonding
STM: visualizes B aggregates in moiré low regions
XPS: C 1s peak characteristic of graphene/Ir(111)
LEED: sharp spots, single rotational domain
DFT calculations (B3LYP functional with cc-pVDZ basis set and D3 dispersion correction)

band_gap_ev.after: dependent on doping site and supercell size (e.g., 0.181 eV for single doping in 2x2, 1.006 eV for double doping in 2x2)

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Smaller size and higher activity of Li compared to Na
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Li migrates closer to the HB surface than Na
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Due to the smaller size and higher activity of the Li element compared to that of the Na type... the former group of atoms tend to migrate closer to the surface.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Li attacks HB bonds and destroys monolayer structure
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: After the optimal concentration (x > 0.5), highly active Li atoms destroy the monolayer structure by attacking the HB bonds.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Na creates a second layer of adatoms instead of destroying monolayer
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Whereas, Na atoms prefer to limit the anode capacity by creating the second layer of adatoms instead of destroying the monolayer structure, and preventing additional electronic charge transfer.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Weaker interaction of Na with HB surface compared to Li
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Easier and faster Na diffusion
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The lower barrier for the Na adatom might be described by weaker interaction between the Na atom with the HB surface (-1.27 eV) compared to that of the small Li element (-2.32 eV), which causes an easier and faster transfer rate for this adatom.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increased formation of insulating MoO3-rich disordered domains
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The significant variation of electronic properties is caused by the creation of insulating MoO3-rich disordered domains in the MoS2 sheet upon oxygen plasma exposure, leading to an exponential variation of resistance and mobility as a function of plasma exposure time.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Lattice distortions
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Therefore, the creation of MoO3 in MoS2 creates significant distortion of lattice which increases with increasing plasma exposure time. The resulting material can be treated as an EMSC which can explain the exponential variation of resistance

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increases work function of exposed region
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: This calculation also suggest that with longer oxygen plasma exposure, the work function of the exposed region increases. For the same reason, the mobility and on-current decreases with plasma exposure time.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Induces spin disproportionation in the Fe sublattices, leading to robust out-of-plane collinear ferrimagnetism.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: spin-disproportionation in heavily-electron-doped versions Lu1−xHfxFeO3 (h-LHFO), especially for x=1/3 and 1/2, leads to robust out-of-plane collinear ferrimagnetism

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Triggers electronic redistribution on the energy axis and a metal-to-insulator transition.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the electronic redistribution on the energy axis is triggered by a polar mode which is a combination of Jahn-Teller distortion and the trimmer distortion. This mode...causes a metal-to-insulator (MIT) transition

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Creates various spin configurations by tuning the Fe+2/Fe+3 ratio.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: various spin configurations can be created by tuning x, namely the Fe+2/Fe+3 ratio

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Reduces inter-layer distance and tunes the interaction between successive layers.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: By applying uni-axial strain along the crystallographic c-axis, the inter-layer distance can be reduced, thereby, we can tune the interaction between the successive layers

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Influences magnetic ordering. Layers with two magnetic sublattices (Fe+2 and Fe+3) exhibit collinear FiM along the c-axis at 100 K.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Whichever layer has two magnetic sublattices features collinear FiM along the crystallographic c-axis at 100 K.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Changes the direction of DMI of MnSTe, enabling skyrmion switching.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Thus, the Te completing the TBP also distorts according to the polarization direction, which results in a change in the direction of the DMI of MnSTe...the skyrmion direction can be switched by switching the polarization direction of h-Lu1/3Hf2/3FeO3

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: F2 bond stretching (∼1.9−2.0 ˚A)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: when ﬂuorine molecules are intercalated between two mono/multilayer graphene, their bonds get stretched enough (∼1.9−2.0 ˚A) to weaken their molecular singlet eigenstate

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: charge transfer from carbon layers to fluorine layers
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: stabilizes triplet and doublet states
causal_relationships.affected_property: induces local spin-moments at each ﬂuorine site
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As there is a signiﬁcant charge transfer from the adjacent carbon layers to the ﬂuorine layers, a mixture of triplet and doublet states stabilize to induce local spin-moments at each ﬂuorine sites

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: weakly bound triplet state
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: if F2 molecule is stretched to the bond distance of 1.9−2.0 ˚A, a weakly bound triplet state is achieved

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: lesser magnetic moment
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Larger the charge transfer lesser the magnetic moment

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: increases intercalation energy
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Increase in charge transfer increases the intercalation energy which perturbs the system

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: AA to AB stacking transition, adatom formation
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the system have transformed to AB stacked bilayer graphene, with F forming covalent bond with C

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: maintains pseudoatomized F even at room temperature
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: ﬂuorine atoms remain pseudoatomized and does not form bond with carbon atoms

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Creation of intimate vdW heterointerfaces between graphene and MoX2
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Over 10-fold accumulation of charge in MoX2 compared to MoX2/MoX2 homointerfaces
More negative intercalation potential by at least 0.5 V compared to bulk MoX2
Intercalation processes occur, revealed by pronounced jumps in Rxx and nH.
Decline in electron mobility as Li+ ions act as scattering sites; Ultimately resistance is driven down as carrier density increases.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Intercalation / electron doping of 2H-MoS2 beyond ~0.35 Li per MoS2 unit
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Structural phase transition from semiconducting H phase to metallic T/T' phase
Enhances electrochemical charge accumulation in MoS2 and shifts intercalation potential more negative than bulk MoS2
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The low resistivity of graphene […] furnishes a lower-resistance electronic pathway […] which allows its immediate interface with the MoX2 layer to undergo ionic doping more efficiently than adjacent MoX2/MoX2 homointerfaces.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Local phase transformation from H-MoS2 to T’-MoS2 upon doping
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Cooperative effect where it becomes increasingly favorable to intercalate Li, lowering the activation barrier for Li+ insertion
causal_relationships.affected_property: Li binding energy, intercalation activation barrier

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Substantially stronger attenuating effect on the binding energy of Li (compared to hBN) , yet still the reaction is more exergonic than that of Li with hBN/G or G/G
modifies electron and phonon temperatures, influencing magnetization dynamics and spin texture formation.
causal_relationships.affected_property: magnetization (Mz/Ms), spin texture type (skyrmions, stripes, bubbles)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: An initial sharp increase of Telec is observed within the sub-picosecond regime (~0.5 ps) taking the system above the Curie temperature TC = 68 K2. Tphon follows the variation of Telec as thermal relaxation takes place shortly after the excitation. The behaviour of both temperatures is dependent on the ﬂuence energy applied to the layers displaying variation on the stabilisation of Telec and Tphon towards equilibration. That is, the higher the ﬂuence the larger the stabilised temperatures. This affects directly how the magnetisation (Mz/Ms) responds to the laser pulse, which is strongly ﬂuence-dependent.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: type-I demagnetization dynamics
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At low ﬂuence magnitudes (e.g., 0.03 mJ cm−2), the demagnetisation process completes before the electron-phonon temperature equilibration is reached (0.34 K). There is a short decay of the magnetisation from the saturation state to Mz/Ms = 0.75 which rapidly recovers on the timescale of ~4 ps. This demagnetisation process can be classiﬁed as type-I dynamics as a single-step demagnetization within the electron-phonon equilibration is achieved.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: type-II demagnetization dynamics
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At higher ﬂuences (i.e., 0.2 mJ cm−2) there is an initial rapid demagnetisation (Mz/Ms = 0.04) of the CrGeTe3 driven by the electron temperature. After the electron-phonon temperature equilibration is achieved (2.25 K) the magnetisation does not signiﬁcantly recover, and instead a second, far slower stage of demagnetisation proceeds which is determined by the phonon temperature. This is a two-stage demagnetisation process deﬁned as a type-II dynamics.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: formation of variety of magnetic objects (bubbles, spirals, stripes, donuts)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Interestingly, between the low and large ﬂuence limits, there is a transitional regime where a rapid and almost complete recovery of the magnetisation occurs within 200 ps initially following a type-I dynamics. Nevertheless, over a much longer timescale ( >200 ps) the system enters in a second demagnetisation stage steered by the phonon temperature as in a type-II dynamics. In this transitional domain, the laser pulse drives the formation of a variety of magnetic objects such as bubbles (circular and elongated), spirals or stripe domains, and donut-shaped textures (e.g., 0.14 mJ cm−2)

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Final topological charge near zero, type-I magnetization dynamics
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At low ﬂuences, 0.001−0.055 mJ cm−2 the ﬁnal topological charge is nearly zero with the magnetisation in the type-I dynamics.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: formation of spin stripes
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As the ﬂuence increases within the range of 0.055−0.087 mJ cm−2, the pulse signiﬁcantly demagnetises the system, creating densely packed magnon droplets transiting the system to the formation of non-trivial objects such as spin stripes.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: formation of skyrmions, sometimes with skyrmioniums
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The formation of skyrmions however can be achieved as the energy is slightly increased to 0.09−0.180 mJ cm−2. At this limit, the temperature of the system is suitable for the magnon droplets to gain topological features, and hence they evolve into skyrmions rather than merging. It is noteworthy that is within the region of 0.14−0.18 mJ cm−2 there is the simultaneous formation of skyrmioniums with skyrmions which are randomly distributed over the surface.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: hybrid spin state of skyrmions, stripes and skyrmioniums
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At ﬂuences above 0.18 mJ cm−2, a hybrid spin state consisting of skyrmions, stripes and skyrmioniums are formed. The large amount of energy deposited in the CrGeTe3 layers at this limit results in thermal ﬂuctuations which are sufﬁcient to inhibit the creation of magnon droplets. Instead, the non-equilibrium spin textures tend to merge and evolve in mixed labyrinthine domains with the appearance of skyrmions and skyrmioniums.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Determines whether magnon droplets form skyrmions/bubbles or stripe domains
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: A closer look at the magnetisation dynamics reveals that depending on the amount of energy transferred to the layers via the different number of pulses N, the magnon droplets can either be isolated and give place to the formation of skyrmions or magnetic bubbles; or, they can coalesce and form long stripe domains with smaller contributions from localised droplets.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: application of laser pulses with magnetic field
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: transformation of magnetic textures (stripes to bubbles/skyrmions and vice versa)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: As laser pulses are applied to CrGeTe3, there are clear transformations of the magnetic textures from one state to another which can be further manipulated via a magnetic ﬁeld.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: controls polarity of created spin textures
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Different ﬁeld polarisation also controls the polarity of the created spin textures (e.g., stripes, bubbles, skyrmions, anti-skyrmions) as we compare the ﬁnal spin state with ﬁelds of different signs.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Geometrically low regions of the moiré superlattice
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Energetically favored for substitutional boron incorporation
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: BC species are the most plausible candidates for the observed defects, since this element is present in the BTHF precursor and, unlike oxygen, was detected by XPS

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Induces local bending of graphene towards Ir(111)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the substitutional boron strongly perturbs the graphene/Ir(111) interaction by inducing a larger charge transfer from the underlying Ir atoms to the carbon atoms

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Local bending of graphene and enhanced charge transfer
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Compensates hole doping induced by substitutional boron
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the holes that they introduce in graphene are compensated by the uptake of electron charges from the substrate through a stronger interfacial interaction

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Highly corrugated moiré superlattice (Ir(111) or Ru(0001))
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Enables site-selective pinning of substitutional boron

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Incorporation of boron during graphene growth
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Enhances boron segregation at elevated temperatures, facilitating access to favorable moiré regions
Increased formation energy (less stable)
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Si atoms closer to the edge are more likely to be substituted than those in the interior sites

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Induces out-of-plane and bond distortions
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: C substitutions...induce significant distortions caused by disorder

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Ferromagnetic behavior
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: all of the doped configurations prefer to be in a triplet state indicating that these structures are ferromagnetic

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: C-C bond in adjacent doping sites (e.g., S12-S14)
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Higher strain, lower stability
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the C-C bond introduces a higher strain into the structures, due to its shorter length, making those nanoclusters the most unstable ones

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Affects HOMO-LUMO gap
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: For single C substitutions near the center have a larger effect on the band gap

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Doping site and number of C atoms
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Affects HOMO-LUMO gap
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: For double C doping, the larger effects on the gap are shown near the edges due to correlation effects and structural relaxation

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Affects band gap
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: For those structures in which the carbon atoms are located at the same sublattice exhibit similar and larger band gaps than those for which the doping occurs in opposite sublattices.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Opens band gap
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: This symmetry-breaking doping induces a sublattice potential difference which in turn breaks the band degeneracy and opens the band gap.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Closes band gap, recovers Dirac cones
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: as the strength of the disorder increases, the gaps close eventually recovering the presence of Dirac cones

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Using H2O as an oxygen precursor in ALD on 2D materials
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Non-uniform and island-like growth on defects or step edges of 2D materials
Provides additional dangling bonds for uniform and homogeneous growth
May lead to damage of the 2D material or unintentional doping
causal_relationships.affected_property: PL quenching and alteration of electronic properties

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Deposition of a thin metal seed layer for ALD
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Decreases mobility of devices and may damage atomically thin 2D semiconductors
Stronger interaction leading to charge density redistribution at the interface and band-gap opening in bilayer graphene
Weak interaction preserving the Dirac cone of graphene layers
Stronger interaction leading to the emergence of mid-gap states
Weak interaction preserving the electronic properties of WSe2

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Oxygen plasma pretreatment of graphite and WSe2 templates before Al2O3 growth
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Al2O3 exfoliates along with the underlying graphite and WSe2 due to oxidation and chemical bond formation

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Direct ALD growth of alumina on WS2 monolayer using O3
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Significant PL quenching (7x) due to doping
Weak interaction with WS2 similar to Al-terminated Al2O3, preventing doping
